titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to her Papers at the Indiana University Archives
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Bethany Fiechter.

change.item: Batch update to change repository name, subject links, preferred citation, and user restrictions.

did.unittitle: Myrtle Scott papers
did.abstract: Myrtle Scott was a professor of educational psychology at Indiana University from 1970 until her retirement in 2002. Her primary teaching responsibilities were in the Human Development program with a focus on child development, while her research interests centered on developmental and ecological psychology. Scott's papers include biographical files, teaching files, publications, and research notes with some correspondence, with the bulk of the collection consisting of Scott's publications and research notes from 1965-2003.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Myrtle Scott Teaching Dossier files are restricted.
Advance notice is required for access to collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Myrtle Scott was born on February 4, 1937, and earned her B.A. from Hardin-Simmons University in 1959 in biology and chemistry, an M.A. in clinical psychology from North Texas State University in 1961, and her Ph.D. from Peabody College (now Vanderbilt University) in 1969. She was appointed to teach at Indiana University in 1970 as a part-time Visiting Assistant Professor, was promoted to Associate Professor in 1971, Professor in 1980 and in 2000 she became a Class of 1948 Herman B Wells Endowed Professor. Income from this fund is used at the discretion of the endowed professor for the materials related to the discipline in which he or she is engaged.

Scott's research and teaching has focused primarily upon developmental and ecological psychology, including the development of new research methods and strategies on human behavior. One of the first tasks Scott undertook at Indiana University was the development of the Interdisciplinary Doctoral Program on Young Children (IDPYC) which emphasized child development, curriculum, and social policy activities. For further information on the IDPYC see Archives Collection C196. She has been widely published on the effects of the environment on human behavior and development.

Scott has received numerous awards for her distinguished service including the Gorman Award for Outstanding Teaching from the IU School of Education in 1994, the Distinguished Service Award in 1997, and the President's Award for Distinguished Teaching in 1995. Scott retired in 2002 with the title of Class of 48 Herman B Wells Endowed Professor Emeritus. She died on January 17, 2016 in Kerrville, Texas.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into three series: Biographical files, Teaching files, and Lectures, research and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Myrtle Scott's papers are organized into three series: Biographical files, Teaching files, and Lectures, research and publications.

Biographical files (1970-2006) include Scott's Faculty Annual Reports, files on her awards, her teaching dossier and an essay written by Scott describing her teaching methods, titled Self-Analysis of Teaching. The awards included within the biographical files are the Service Award in 1997 and the Pinnell Award in 1999. The Service Award folder includes nominations, Scott's Vita from August 23, 1997, and general correspondence. The Pinnell Award in 1999 includes correspondence, a picture of Scott, and a copy of the newsletter regarding her nomination for the award.

Scott's teaching files consist of syllabi, handouts, and various notes relating to the classes that she taught at Indiana University from the 1980s until 2001. The classes represented within this series include Advanced Child Development, Child Development, Life-Span Development, and Doctoral Seminar in Educational Psychology: Theory in Development, and Life-Span Development.

Arranged chronologically, the vast majority of Scott's collection consists of her lectures, research and publications from 1965-2001. Scott's primary research area is Ecological Psychology and many of her lectures and publications stem from that subject area.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: The donor(s) of this collection have not transferred their copyrights for the materials to the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Myrtle Scott papers, Collection C370, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.
